articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Handling of Email Issue Frustrates Democratic Leaders
articles.snippet: Concerns are growing that Hillary Rodham Clinton is not treating the matter seriously, or doing enough to put it to rest before it harms her 2016 run and other Democrats’ campaigns.
articles.abstract: Concerns are growing that Hillary Rodham Clinton is not treating the matter seriously, or doing enough to put it to rest before it harms her 2016 run and other Democrats’ campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders are increasingly frustrated by Hillary Rodham Clinton’s failure to put to rest questions about her State Department email practices and ease growing doubts among voters about her honesty and trustworthiness.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Money Managers Look for Stock Bargains in Turmoil
articles.snippet: Fund investors are looking for opportunities in global stock markets, where share prices have been battered in recent days.
articles.abstract: Fund investors are looking for opportunities in global stock markets, where share prices have been battered in recent days.
articles.lead_paragraph: The steep market sell-off has spared hardly anyone. Even some of the country’s top-performing portfolio managers have been hit. A fund run by William Miller, the Legg Mason Opportunity Trust, gave back all of this year’s gains of 14 percent. Bill Smead, who manages the Smead Value Fund, lost about 10 percent over the last month. Both funds are now roughly flat over the last year.

articles.headline: Labor Board Ruling Eases Way for Fast-Food Unions’ Efforts
articles.snippet: A ruling by the National Labor Relations Board made it substantially easier for unions to bargain for higher wages and benefits.
articles.abstract: A ruling by the National Labor Relations Board made it substantially easier for unions to bargain for higher wages and benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Labor Relations Board, in a long-awaited ruling, made it easier on Thursday for unions to negotiate on behalf of workers at fast-food chains and other companies relying on contractors and franchisees.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: U.S. Open Stars Juggle Preparation With Publicity
articles.snippet: The week leading up to the tennis tournament is a marketing extravaganza for companies represented by elite players.
articles.abstract: The week leading up to the tennis tournament is a marketing extravaganza for companies represented by elite players.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nike organized street tennis for Maria Sharapova, Roger Federer and others in the meatpacking district. Tommy Hilfiger opted for strip tennis with Rafael Nadal in Bryant Park. Delta Air Lines held a celebrity karaoke night with Serena Williams near Times Square. And American Express staged what it called a “hydro-interactive tennis experience” featuring Ms. Sharapova along the Hudson River.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Ben Rothenberg

articles.headline: Carlyle Finds Hedge Funds Hazardous as Its Private Equity Business Dominates
articles.snippet: Carlyle’s core buyout business continues to exceed Wall Street’s expectations, but its track record on hedge funds has been mixed, raising questions on its ability to diversify.
articles.abstract: Carlyle’s core buyout business continues to exceed Wall Street’s expectations, but its track record on hedge funds has been mixed, raising questions on its ability to diversify.
articles.lead_paragraph: If nothing else, the last week has proved it can be very difficult to run a hedge fund. The Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, has known that for much longer.

articles.headline: Virginia Shooting Spotlights Riddle of Workplace Safety
articles.snippet: What to do with a volatile, aggrieved worker like Vester Lee Flanagan II, who killed two television employees during a live broadcast Wednesday, can be a nightmare for employers.
articles.abstract: What to do with a volatile, aggrieved worker like Vester Lee Flanagan II, who killed two television employees during a live broadcast Wednesday, can be a nightmare for employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The problems were flagrant, and his boss began to document them, only months after Vester Lee Flanagan II started working as a reporter at television station WDBJ in Roanoke, Va.
articles.byline: By Erik Eckholm and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Iran Deal Opens a Vitriolic Divide Among American Jews
articles.snippet: Jewish lawmakers who support the nuclear deal with Iran have been likened to Nazi collaborators, and those who oppose it have been called traitors.
articles.abstract: Jewish lawmakers who support the nuclear deal with Iran have been likened to Nazi collaborators, and those who oppose it have been called traitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attacks on Representative Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of New York, since he announced his support for the nuclear accord with Iran have been so vicious that the National Jewish Democratic Council and the Anti-Defamation League both felt compelled this week to publicly condemn Jewish voices of hate.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: European Publishers Play Lobbying Role Against Google
articles.snippet: An alliance of newspaper and magazine publishers has taken an increasingly active role in fighting the growing dominance of the tech giant.
articles.abstract: An alliance of newspaper and magazine publishers has taken an increasingly active role in fighting the growing dominance of the tech giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In private sessions this summer, giant publishers and media companies from Germany, France and elsewhere have met with European officials about proposals to regulate Europe’s digital economy. The discussions have covered a broad range of contentious issues, according to public disclosures and several people who attended or were briefed on the meetings. Central to almost all of them has been limiting the reach of a single American company: Google.
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Myanmar Democracy Icon Finds Herself Assailed as Authoritarian
articles.snippet: As landmark elections approach, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate, is being openly criticized by activists, commentators and intellectuals.
articles.abstract: As landmark elections approach, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate, is being openly criticized by activists, commentators and intellectuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Framed photographs of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate, cover the walls of his small living room, but U Myo Khin, a longtime democracy activist, has harsh words for the woman he idolized for years as a crusader against dictatorship.

articles.headline: Steady Financial Advice, With Friendship as a Bonus
articles.snippet: It is rare to meet actual orphans with stock portfolios, let alone ones who have hung on to investments for nearly 50 years.
articles.abstract: It is rare to meet actual orphans with stock portfolios, let alone ones who have hung on to investments for nearly 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Anxiety-prone investors looking for safety in the stock market have sometimes found it in so-called widows-and-orphans stocks. At their best, they pay dividends for decades and bounce around a bit less when the markets convulse, as they have over the last week. For years, AT&T was the textbook example. Procter & Gamble was another.

articles.headline: Zombie Factories Stalk the Sputtering Chinese Economy
articles.snippet: The government is keeping failing factories on life support in an effort to maintain social stability, but the policy may hinder a return to healthy growth.
articles.abstract: The government is keeping failing factories on life support in an effort to maintain social stability, but the policy may hinder a return to healthy growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Miao Leijie loses money on each ton of cement his company produces. But stopping production is not an option.

articles.headline: Ashley Madison Chief Steps Down After Data Breach
articles.snippet: The change came after hackers stole the online dating service’s data and released personal information related to more than 30 million accounts.
articles.abstract: The change came after hackers stole the online dating service’s data and released personal information related to more than 30 million accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last two years, online attacks have led to executive casualties at prominent companies like Sony Pictures Entertainment and Target. Now add to the list the chief executive of the company operating the adultery website Ashley Madison, a lesser known but far more salacious victim.

articles.headline: An S.E.C. Settlement With Citigroup That Fails to Name Names
articles.snippet: The Citi employees whose strategy led to $2 billion in investor losses have not been pursued or even identified.
articles.abstract: The Citi employees whose strategy led to $2 billion in investor losses have not been pursued or even identified.
articles.lead_paragraph: How can we expect Wall Street’s me-first culture to change when regulators won’t pursue or even identify the me-firsters who are directly involved?
